Award.AwardTitle: MKP1 regulates plant metabolite signals that induce bacterial virulence: How and where are these signals controlled?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many plants normally become infected by bacterial pathogens that then cause reduced food yields or even death. However, the investigators recently discovered a mutant plant with a novel mechanism for enhanced resistance against bacterial pathogens whereby the plant prevents the bacteria from becoming infectious. In this project, the investigators will determine how the mutant uniquely stops the pathogen by studying both the location of and the mechanism(s) controlling this resistance. The investigators will also examine if the mutant has enhanced resistance against other types of pathogens (e.g. fungal pathogens) or if the mutation causes a trade-off of enhanced resistance against one type of pathogen at the expense of increased susceptibility to another. The goal of this project is to determine if there is a novel, genetic means of improving crop survival against pathogens without any unintended penalties.

Most pathogenic bacteria express a type three secretion system (T3SS) to suppress the plant's immune responses, thus allowing the pathogen to acquire nutrients needed to replicate. The investigators recently identified an Arabidopsis mutant (mkp1) that produces less of the chemical signals that induce the T3SS in bacteria, thus resulting in a plant with enhanced resistance. Translating this discovery into improved resistance in the field requires a better understanding of the underlying principles. Does MKP1 regulate levels of transporters controlling movement of metabolites across the plasma membrane (PM) to restrict the chemical signals (addressed by quantitative plasma membrane proteomics)? Does MKP1 regulate the cellular production of these metabolites (addressed by quantitative metabolomics)? Do all cell types in the leaf contribute equally to the production of the metabolites and, therefore, resistance (addressed by cell/tissue-specific complementation? Finally, it is critical to test an informative spectrum of pathogens to determine if resistance in mkp1 extends to other types of pathogens or, perhaps more importantly, if the changes in mkp1 may have negative consequences making it more susceptible to unrelated pathogens. A better understanding of this apparently novel mechanism of resistance may provide an important basis for improving sustainable resistance in the field. The investigators will expand a Plant Biology & Public Policy Workshop they developed for undergraduates where students learn how policy makers at the local, state, and national level affect research at universities. Students will learn to communicate the importance of basic research by providing the most useful information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacterial pathogens of plants infect the host, thereby decreasing yield and food production, by injecting effector proteins into plant cells to shut down the plant's immune response. However, bacterial pathogens only activate this virulence process when they chemically recognize a host. We had previously identified a mutant plant lacking a protein, MKP1, that did not accumulate chemical signals required by the pathogens outside the plant cells, making these "stealth" plants more resistant to infection. As this is a new mechanism of plant resistance, the goal of this work was to understand how this process is controlled by the plant to provide future avenues for breeding plants that better prevent infections. In this work, we demonstrated that it is transport rather than synthesis of the chemical signals that is altered as there were no significant differences in the overall abundance of the chemicals within the plant. Thus, the goal of this grant became understanding how secretion is controlled.

We first demonstrated that the resistance in plants lacking MKP1 did not require the plant defense hormone, salicylic acid (SA), by performing genetic crosses with mutants that either did not produce or could not perceive SA. Moreover, the restriction in effector delivery is also not dependent on SA. These results are significant because much of what is known currently about plant defense response involves SA. Although it has been known that SA-independent defense(s) exist, there are very few defined genetic modifiers of this process. Therefore, this work has clearly defined one of the first signaling pathways leading to SA-independent resistance. The broader implications of these results is that one form of early defense responses, called pattern-triggered immunity (PTI) because it is activated in the plant when it recognizes molecular patterns from the bacteria), is known to be also independent of SA. Our previous work showed large similarities between plants lacking MKP1 and plants with pre-induced PTI; and establishing that resistance is SA-independent provides further evidence that understanding the processes affected in mkp1 mutants provides the basis for defining the mechanisms underlying PTI.

Towards this goal, we identified a new key component in this defense pathway that is normally required for resistance, both in plants lacking MKP1 and in plants undergoing an induced PTI. However, plants lacking this protein, ATL6, are able to perform most molecular responses associated with PTI normally. These results indicate that ATL6 functions either downstream or independently of these responses, likely close to the site of action of how plants manifest defense. The present work indicates a model whereby the function of this protein, ATL6, regulates the activity or the abundance of cellular transporters that control the extracellular availability of the chemical signals required by the pathogen to induce their virulence program. Plants lacking this protein are unable to restrict the availability of the chemical signals, rendering plants unable to stop pathogen infection. These are testable hypotheses that, if true, would provide new strategies for rationally designing plants with enhanced resistance against bacterial pathogens, thereby increasing yields for American farmers and cheaper, more secure food supplies for consumers. By performing a large-scale analysis of membrane proteins altered in abundance either during PTI or in the mkp1 mutant, we have identified a relatively small list of candidate proteins that may play roles in mediating plant resitance, setting the stage to test the larger hypothesis.

In addition to the new information generated by this work, two important aspects of Broader Impacts were achieved. A number of young scientists, including 3 PhD students and 1 postdoctoral researcher, were trained in advanced biochemical and molecular techniques, thus improving the qualifications of those entering the US workforce. In addition, a 1-day workshop on Plant Biology and Public Policy was held with 44 young scientists from 9 institutes. This workshop educated the scientists about how government decisions are made and how to best communicate useful information to local and national lawmakers. Improved communication will both help advocacy for science research and assist scientists in being better resources of information for lawmakers.
